Award.AwardTitle: Multimodal signal amplification by collaborative plasmonic intensification and catalytic multiplication (c-PI/CM)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Shih, Wei-Chuan
Proposal No: 1605683

Very sensitive measurement of disease-indicating molecules in body fluids is essential for delivering quality healthcare. This project aims to develop a new approach that is expected to be both sensitive and reliable. The new approach is based on synergy of light-excited electron oscillation and chemical reaction occuring simultaneously on specialized nanostructures.


In biosensing, an unmet need is ultrasensitive detection (like polymerase chain reaction, PCR) with accurate quantitation (like enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, ELISA). This ability is sorely needed for protein biomarkers which cannot be PCR-amplified, or constrained by time, sample quantity, or resources. To meet this need, a novel concept of multimodal signal amplification by collaborative plasmonic intensification and catalytic multiplication (c-PI/CM) is proposed. The central intellectual merit is to exploit the collaborative synergy between PI and CM. Collaborative PI/CM is not simply enhancing one modality by the other, but the collaboration and positive reinforcement between the two modalities. Thus, PI/CM is fundamentally different from, for example, plasmon-enhanced ELISA. To test this hypothesis, the PI will design a series of experiments to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of c-PI/CM by investigating their interplay on standard plasmonic nanostructures fabricated by nanolithography. A second hypothesis is to test whether c-PI/CM would perform better on recently developed nanoporous gold (NPG) disks which exhibits intrinsic catalytic functions, high-density, three dimensionally distributed plasmonic field enhancement sites (also known as, hot spots), order-of-magnitude larger surface area, and excellent structural integrity and environmental stability, all pointing to a more plausible high-performance c-PI/CM platform. Several in situ monitoring techniques will be used to assess sensing performance: LSPR shift, surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS), and surface-enhanced fluorescence (SEF).

POR.DRECONTENT:
To achieve both ultrasensitive detection like polymerase chain reaction (PCR) with accurate quantitation like enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), the PI proposes to investigate a novel concept of multimodal signal amplification by collaborative plasmonic intensification and catalytic multiplication (c-PI/CM). The central research effort is to exploit the collaborative synergy between PI and CM.

To test this hypothesis, the PI has designed a series of experiments to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms behind c-PI/CM by studying their interplay on standard plasmonic nanostructures fabricated by nanolithography. A specific plasmonic system of focus is arrayed nanoporous gold (ANG) disks that feature radiative coupling, internal ~10 nm porous network, and intrinsic catalytic effect.  

The major outcomes of this project falls into three general categories: (1) understanding AGN plasmonic behavior for better plasmonic substrate engineering, (2) investigate model systems for c-PI/CM, and (3) develop new application to take advantage of c-PI/CM.

To understand AGN plasmonic behavior, we have discovered radiative coupling effects among the plasmonic array, which has been overlooked in the past. The radiative coupling results in plasmonic shift and can be employed to engineer the LSPR peak position. It also applies to different materials such as gold, alloy, and nanoporous gold. We also discover another mechanism for generating green LSPR peak by superstrate-substrate asymmetry. This LSPR peak centers at 540 nm is particularly useful for visible light applications.

We have studied the catalytic reduction of resazurin to resorufin, a well studied pathway on gold nanoparticles. We have shown that light-excited plasmons can enhance the catalytic reaction by 10-fold, which would open up new applications by harvesting the sunlight. We have also studied the potential of sensing a biological enzyme, telomerase, on plasmonic substrate by surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy. We showed that the catalytic property of telomerase produce more detection signal.

We have developed several molecular sensing assays for small molecules such as malachite green and demonstrate potential application in detecting this carcinogen in fish meat.

Overall, the findings of this project have laid the ground work for synergistic effect of plasmon and catalysis on various plasmonic nanostructures, and will be highly relevant to the development of practical applications.
